video.title: Assembly Language Programming with ARM – Full Tutorial for Beginners
video.description:
Learn assembly language programming with ARMv7 in this beginner's course. 🦾

ARM is becoming an increasingly popular language in the world of computer programming. It is estimated that over 200 billion devices contain an ARM chip, making the ARM language valuable to understand. By understanding an assembly language, programmers can have a better understanding of how code is compiled and run, making it possible to create more efficient programs. In addition to this, programmers can work at a lower level, allowing them to write code that interacts with hardware in an efficient manner.

✏️ Scott Cosentino created this course. Check out his YouTube channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC7KBXRtv-EkiOFsRtpBxIbg

💻 Emulator for ARM programming: https://cpulator.01xz.net/?sys=arm-de1soc

⭐️ Course Contents ⭐️
⌨️ (0:00:00) Introduction
⌨️ (0:01:08) Intro and Setup
⌨️ (0:03:33) Emulation and Memory Layout
⌨️ (0:13:22) Your First Program
⌨️ (0:24:39) Addressing Modes
⌨️ (0:37:10) Arithmetic and CPSR Flags
⌨️ (0:48:38) Logical Operations
⌨️ (0:55:03) Logical Shifts and Rotations Part 1
⌨️ (1:02:23) Logical Shifts and Rotations Part 2
⌨️ (1:09:06) Conditions and Branches
⌨️ (1:19:37) Loops with Branches
⌨️ (1:29:16) Conditional Instruction Execution
⌨️ (1:34:36) Branch with link register and returns
⌨️ (1:41:05) Preserving and Retrieving Data From Stack Memory
⌨️ (1:49:49) Hardware Interactions
⌨️ (1:58:07) Setting up Qemu for ARM
⌨️ (2:07:52) Printing Strings to Terminal
⌨️ (2:20:26) Debugging Arm Programs with Gdb

🎉 Thanks to our Champion and Sponsor supporters:
👾 Raymond Odero
👾 Agustín Kussrow
👾 aldo ferretti
👾 Otis Morgan
👾 DeezMaster

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://freecodecamp.org/news

topLevelComment.author: salec
topLevelComment.text:
Sorry to point out this, but you are confusing viewers with such interpretation of Little endian and Big endian. First, note that regardless of processor endian-ness, the number in a multi-byte register will always be represented with most significant figure to the left (the way we write numbers on paper). The only difference will be in that which byte is at which address within address range of the register, and that would be important only if we iterate over bytes one at a time (e.g. sending an array of them to a character device in correct order).
It is Big endian if the most significant byte is at address offset 0 from the base address of the register (the way we usually write and read numbers).
It is Little endian if least significant byte is at address offset 0 from the base address of the register.

Apparently, Big endian arrangement comes "naturally" from our historical representation of Arab (Indian) numeral numbers, but Little endian is arrangement which had unique advantage: it enabled much cleaner (a single, simpler iterative loop) multi-word arithmetics (addition and subtraction), especially if the numbers were of different lengths (so we would start e.g. adding them  lower parts first, and if there was a carry, we would take it into account in next iteration with higher numeral positions).

topLevelComment.author: Jorge Ferreira
topLevelComment.text:
You got me confused.
Since when a "data" segment is the same as the "stack"?
I'm trying to get acquainted with the ARM architecture and instruction set, but it only took 30 minutes to hear something that goes against everything I learned before.
Calling "stack" to the bulk system memory is against the most basic computer science principles. The "stack" name refers to an area of memory with very specific rules of access and usage.
- With an AND operation it might be really interesting to have the "Z"ero flag set by "ANDS". Just think working with bitmaps even in high level languages. Not to mention an testing input pins in an embedded system.

1:52:43 - The whole explanation around the "SWITCH" equate is a mess. Its perfectly possible to put the hexadecimal constant directly in the "ldr" instruction. It would be better explained has a convenience to avoid the "magic numbers" symptom along the program code.
Why are those peripherals, switches and LEDs, being accessed as if they were memory? Don't bother, I know the answer. But others may not.

2:07:52 and forward
"\n" interpreted by the operating system as a newline character !?!?!?!??!
The "\n" text is interpreted by the assembler (as) as the ASCII control character 'NL' (newline) with code '10' (0x0a). The Operating system, linux or other will send it as is to the device driver that, in a printer os display terminal is translated to a change of line.

The "Hello World" string stored in "stack" memory !?!?!?!? Better take a look at the stack pointer to see its pointing somewhere else, probably in a totally different memory region.
The ".data" is placed in a memory region commonly known as "initialized data".

I'm out of here.!!!
This video is way bellow the "freeCodeCamp" quality level that I've found in other videos.

topLevelComment.author: Louis Carliner
topLevelComment.text: For business and other commercial applications, little endian hardware arrangements can be a booby trap, especially with old higher-level languages, such as old COBOL compilers and Fortran, as if one storage areas use the "redefine" construct in whicy a character array has a word array alternate construct, a program that was written for use on IBM or Prime computers, both of which are big endian in structure, and is ported to a Digital equipment machine, which is little endian in design, the program behavior is likely to be erroneous in it operation. With newer COBOL language versions, which have been enhances to provided needed alphanumeric data manipulations constructs, the use of redefines using different datatypes is no longer needed. Little endian architecture provided interesting hardware design shortcuts have no place in modern application design! The could be a reason that Prime computer architecture was more successful in business companies than Digital Euipment products.

replies.author: Jorge Ferreira
replies.text:
Totally wrong.
Humans that know what they are doing will ever right better low level code than a compiler.
The drawbacks of coding in assembly are:
1 - Its quite fastidious to code in such detail
2 - Its error prone because of the number of low level detail you need to handle.
3 - Its a lot of work when you need to deal with the same kind of tasks and data used in desktop or server software.
What happens in the real world is that:
In desktop: Use C++, to write the bulk of the program and assembly for a couple of special functions that perform some task that is way to slow when written by a compiler.
In embedded: Use assembly to some time critical signal generation related with the hardware, like pumping some waveform the I/O pins of a Raspberry Pi.
Not to mention some use cases when you write a program in assembly using some C/C++ functions to do the fastidious handling of complex data structures.
In some micro controllers, the amount of available program space and data memory is so small that its almost useless for compiled code. So one uses ASM.

topLevelComment.author: Robin Deatherage
topLevelComment.text:
Unless your tied into Assembly through either C or C ++, most language development will fail. Why? 

For starters the underlying Unix or  Mimicked Unix base is already tied into the file system, the graphics windowing system either x19 or win32 and utilizes the cut, copy and paste utilities. 

All programing in Assembly will not advance anything the C languages have already taken over forty plus years to test, implant and make useful for all languages. So unless your doing Assembly as a hobby, would be your thing. Otherwise it's a lost cause. 

Also languages such as CPython and Rust are both C and C++ respectfully are the exception to that rule. And just imagine, both are an already compiled language processing loop long before their token streams are processed. Rust uses the backdoor of the GCC Compiler which makes it C based and needs no conversion to Assembly whatsoever. Imagine that, a token stream being read into a loop, processed then executed by an already compiled language which requires no assembly because it's running in Machine Binary.

topLevelComment.author: Éric Bischoff
topLevelComment.text:
I thinks that what is called the "stack" here, is the data segment instead.
In the video, the emulator confirms this as =list is indexed on the PC register, not on the stack pointer SP.
At   29:11    ldr r0,[pc, #-4]
You can also see in the source code that this program accesses the data segment, because ".data" is used.

replies.author: Éric Bischoff
replies.text:
@Christopher Gabriel Right. Thanks for the precision that explains the negative sign I missed. I have corrected.

That was not my point though. My point was, it's not the "stack" as the speaker says.

replies.author: Christopher Gabriel
replies.text:
The program counter is actually pointing two instructions ahead [1], hence ldr r0, [pc,#-4] loads the value at address 4 (8-4 = 4) into r0. Notice the negative immediate offset. CPUlator does not show the correct content for the PC in the register view but the inline comment of that instruction "; 4" shows the correct address for the indirect load. At memory address 4 you have the value 8, which is the actual address of the list as you already mentioned.
[1] ARM Architecture Reference Manual ARMv7-A and ARMv7-R edition

topLevelComment.author: Richard Eigenmann
topLevelComment.text:
This is such a helpful introduction to assemply language programming. I loved it! Last time I did Assembler was on the 6502 processor back in the 1980ies... I love the emulator in the webpage. Makes following what is going on really easy.
However, the hello world program didn't work for me on my Raspberry Pi. I think that is because the example is for a 32bit processor and my Pi is 64bit. The names of the registers have changed and the numbers for the syscalls are also different! Here is the modified version that works: 

global _start
_start:
        MOV X0,#1
        LDR X1, =message
        LDR X2, =len
        MOV W8, #64
        SVC #0

        MOV X0, #0
        MOV W8, #93
        SVC #0

.data
message:
        .asciz "Hello World\n"
len = .-message

replies.author: DashNode
replies.text: Embedded microcontroller and their (often) limited memory resources... Sometimes you need to squeeze every bit of performance (e.g. critical interrupt handlers) or limit the number of instructions your program uses in order to meet memory requirements. An extreme example would be the PIC10F200 and its 384 bytes of program flash + 16 bytes of RAM. But when memory is not a big problem (which is the case even in the lowest range of ARM MCU's), C can be used and produce very good results performance-wise, I agree. Appart from this, assembly language is a nice way to get familiar with your processor's architecture/hardware, though.

replies.author: Ray Bod
replies.text: Normal language… assembler tells a processor what to do step by step… like multiple this number at this memory location by this number at this memory location,  go to this line of instructions to do next, stop.  It’s using the most basic instructions possible.  Why?  Because it’s as efficient as can be and there are no limitations.  Anything that can be programmed, can be programmed in assembler.  Down side, it takes a long time to program, errors can be catastrophic and difficult to find.
